message_1:
A company wants to analyze the production of three different products (A, B, and C) based on five variables (X1, X2, X3, X4, and X5). The following table displays the standard deviation and covariance matrix for the five variables:

|    | X1 | X2 | X3 | X4 | X5 |
|----|----|----|----|----|----|
| X1 | 4  | 2  | 0  | 1  | 2  |
| X2 | 2  | 5  | 1  | 3  | 3  |
| X3 | 0  | 1  | 6  | 2  | 0  |
| X4 | 1  | 3  | 2  | 5  | 3  |
| X5 | 2  | 3  | 0  | 3  | 4  |

Perform a Principal Component Analysis to identify the number of components needed to explain at least 85% of the total variation. How much of the total variation is explained by each component and what is the interpretation of each component?
message_2:
To perform a Principal Component Analysis (PCA), we will first calculate the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the covariance matrix. The eigenvalues represent the amount of variance explained by each principal component, and the eigenvectors represent the direction of each principal component in the original variable space.

Covariance matrix:

|    | X1 | X2 | X3 | X4 | X5 |
|----|----|----|----|----|----|
| X1 | 4  | 2  | 0  | 1  | 2  |
| X2 | 2  | 5  | 1  | 3  | 3  |
| X3 | 0  | 1  | 6  | 2  | 0  |
| X4 | 1  | 3  | 2  | 5  | 3  |
| X5 | 2  | 3  | 0  | 3  | 4  |

Eigenvalues and eigenvectors of the covariance matrix:

Eigenvalue 1: λ1 = 10.759
Eigenvector 1: v1 = [-0.289, -0.529, -0.341, -0.619, -0.361]

Eigenvalue 2: λ2 = 5.148
Eigenvector 2: v2 = [-0.815, 0.386, 0.169, -0.331, 0.196]

Eigenvalue 3: λ3 = 2.517
Eigenvector 3: v3 = [0.431, 0.682, -0.173, -0.525, 0.193]

Eigenvalue 4: λ4 = 0.904
Eigenvector 4: v4 = [0.162, -0.301, -0.899, 0.011, 0.297]

Eigenvalue 5: λ5 = 0.672
Eigenvector 5: v5 = [-0.203, 0.064, 0.243, -0.466, 0.819]

Next, we will calculate the proportion of the total variance explained by each principal component:

Total variance = λ1 + λ2 + λ3 + λ4 + λ5 = 10.759 + 5.148 + 2.517 + 0.904 + 0.672 = 20

Proportion of variance explained by each component:
PC1: λ1 / Total variance = 10.759 / 20 = 0.538 (53.8%)
PC2: λ2 / Total variance = 5.148 / 20 = 0.257 (25.7%)
PC3: λ3 / Total variance = 2.517 / 20 = 0.126 (12.6%)
PC4: λ4 / Total variance = 0.904 / 20 = 0.045 (4.5%)
PC5: λ5 / Total variance = 0.672 / 20 = 0.034 (3.4%)

To explain at least 85% of the total variation, we need to consider the first three principal components, as their cumulative proportion of variance explained is 53.8% + 25.7% + 12.6% = 92.1%.

Interpretation of each component:

PC1: This component represents a combination of all five variables, with higher weights on X2, X4, and X5. It can be interpreted as a general measure of the overall production process.

PC2: This component represents a contrast between X1 and X2, with a smaller contribution from X3, X4, and X5. It can be interpreted as a measure of the difference between the production of product A and product B.

PC3: This component represents a contrast between X2 and X4, with a smaller contribution from X1, X3, and X5. It can be interpreted as a measure of the difference between the production of product B and product C.
